description: From Late Latin offertorium, from the participle stem of offere (“to offer”).

entries.meaning: (Christianity) A prayer said or sung as an anthem while offerings of bread and wine are placed on the altar during the Roman Catholic Mass or the Anglican Communion service. [from 14th c.]
(Christianity) The part of the Eucharist service when offerings of bread and wine are placed on the altar and when any collection is taken; also, the money or other things collected. [from 15th c.]
examples: Before a month had passed the congregation at the evening service at St. Asaph's Church was so slender that the offertory, as Mr. Furlong senior himself calculated, was scarcely sufficient to pay the overhead charge of collecting it.

entries.meaning: (Christianity, historical) A linen or silken cloth anciently used in various ceremonies connected with the administration of the Eucharist.
